conclusion: To determine the maximum distance between Car A and Car B, analyze their positions as functions of time.
The position s(t) can be found by integrating the velocity v(t).
Car A has a constant velocity of 40 m/s from t = 0 to t = 30 seconds.
The position function for Car A is s_A(t) = 40t for 0 ≤ t ≤ 30.
Car B has a constant velocity of 0 m/s from t = 0 to t = 10 seconds.
Car B accelerates linearly from 0 m/s to 40 m/s from t = 10 to t = 20 seconds.
Car B maintains a constant velocity of 40 m/s from t = 20 to t = 30 seconds.
The position function for Car B is s_B(t) = 0 for 0 ≤ t < 10.
The position function for Car B is s_B(t) = 20(t - 10)^2 for 10 ≤ t < 20.
Calculate s_B(20) = 2000.
The position function for Car B is s_B(t) = 40t + 1200 for 20 ≤ t ≤ 30.
Find positions at t = 30: s_A(30) = 1200, s_B(30) = 2400.
Determine maximum distance when Car B overtakes Car A.
Solve 20(t - 10)^2 = 40t for t between 10 and 20.
Solve quadratic equation t^2 - 22t + 100 = 0.
Distance at t = 15.76 is 33.152.
Distance at t = 30 is 1200.
The maximum distance between Car A and Car B is 1200.
